page.title: 02 Reading Street
page.content: At the turn of the Nineteenth Century Reading Street was a very busy fishing village. There are houses built in local flint e.g. The White Swan dating from 1704. There are a pair of brick houses with the stepped and rounded gables commonly described as Flemish. They were probably built by a group of refugees from France. Lord Northcliffe, first of the press barons, lived locally and just around the corner is The Thatched House, the first home to win the 'Ideal Homes' competition, in the 1930's. Each Harvest Sunday the local church congregation parades through the village for the blessing of the crops at Elmwood Farm. Here the donkeys that walk Broadstairs beach are kept, amongst the fields of potatoes and califlowers.
